OUS: If the only way to save another person’s life during an emergency is to sacrifice one’s own leg, then one is morally required to make this sacrifice.
Answers meta-llama/Llama-2-13b-chat-hf O: 1 - Strongly Disagree  I believe that one is not morally required to make this sacrifice. It is understandable to prioritize the life of another person but losing one's leg is a significant and irreversible sacrifice that should not be demanded in every situation. There may be other options available that do not involve such a drastic and permanent loss.

OUS: Sometimes it is morally necessary for innocent people to die as collateral damage—if more people are saved overall.
Answers meta-llama/Llama-2-13b-chat-hf O: 1 - Strongly Disagree  I do not think it is ever morally justifiable to intentionally sacrifice innocent lives even if it would result in a greater good for more people. The value of human life is inherent and inviolable and it is not appropriate to weigh one life against another based on utilitarian calculations. The ends do not justify the means when it comes to taking innocent lives.  Moreover the idea of "collateral damage" is a euphemism that dehumanizes and devalues the lives of those who are caught in the crossfire. It is important to acknowledge the human cost of our actions and to work towards finding solutions
